column4: i know there are some models which do not yet have drivers for 12.04 (like mine gtx 560)
i have no problems dual monitors one for DVI other with VGA->DVI adapter
then check it, nvidia has delays with drivers for linux OS
getting any error message or sth?
so we know if its software center or something else

I'm not sure where you're getting the idea your gtx560 is not supported by the driver in 12.04 ... the driver is version 295.40 and gtx is quite clearly on the Supported Products at http://www.nvidia.com/object/linux-display-amd64-295.40-driver (64bit) and at http://www.nvidia.com/object/linux-display-ia32-295.40-driver ( 32 bit)
If you have been swapping out a bunch of networking cards in the same box, you may want to clear out the contents of /etc/udev/rules.d/70-persistent-net.rules
You can use the trick of reversing their ethX designations in the 70-persistent-net.rules file I directed you at earlier
the file has nothing but comments right now
Interesting. Usually lines like: SUBSYSTEM=="net", ACTION=="add", DRIVERS=="?*", ATTR{address}=="00:1d:72:ed:4b:9e", ATTR{dev_id}=="0x0", ATTR{type}=="1", KERNEL=="eth*", NAME="eth0"
So when two lines and one is eth0 the other eth1, you can just reverse them in there, takes effect next boot
I haven't tried that but it *should* work. Maybe move it someplace safe though first
Are you shutting the machine down in a clean way usually?
That is not really a "clean" way
